tossups.question: In a Medieval legend, this person is humiliated after the emperor’s daughter leaves him hanging in a basket. This person coined the phrase “time flies” in a work whose third book contains an account of the Noric cattle plague. This author wrote “Love conquers all: all must yield to love” in the tenth and final poem of a collection whose fourth poem claims the Golden Age will arrive when a (*) baby is born, which early Christians thought referred to the birth of Jesus. After noticing a belt taken from the corpse of Pallas, the protagonist of a poem by this author slays Turnus. This author of the Georgics and the Eclogues began an epic poem with the line “I sing of arms and the man.” For 10 points, name this author who wrote about a Trojan prince in the Aeneid.
tossups.answer: Virgil [or Vergil; or Publius Vergilius Maro]

tossups.question: These structures are damaged by excess salt efflorescence in Bynesian decay. The boundaries of these non-fruit fly structures are regulated by selective expression of engrailed. The periostracum is a chitinous membrane on the exterior of these structures, which form within the extrapallial space. Aspein is an unusually acidic matrix protein found in the prismatic layer of these structures. Multiple chambers within these structures are connected by the porous siphuncle as a means of regulating (*) buoyancy. Perlucin and nacrein are major protein components of a layer in these structures. Lower levels of aragonite saturation hinders the formation of these structures as a consequence of ocean acidification. For 10 points, name these calcified mollusk exoskeletons.
tossups.answer: sea shells [accept any specific types of animals in front of shell: clam/oyster/snail/nautilus/etc.]

tossups.question: According to one source, this event was carried out by the hero Hotherus in order to win the hand of Gewar's daughter. A vision of an empty bed that is given to Vegtam the Wanderer predicted this event. After a Völva refused to reveal more information about this event, a god curses her by calling her the "mother of three giants." Rinda's son Vali was tasked with avenging this event and refuses to wash his hands or comb his hair until he does. Hermod's attempt to undo this event fails due to the giantess (*) Thokkr's refusal to weap. During a commemoration of this event, the goddess Nanna throws herself on a funeral pyre. This event precedes the Fimbulwinter and causes Ragnorak. For 10 points, name this event where a son of Odin was killed by the blind Hodr throwing mistletoe.
tossups.answer: death of Baldr [accept equivalents like Hodr killing Baldr or Baldr being hit with mistletoe; do NOT accept or prompt on answers mentioning "Baldr's funeral]

tossups.question: In this country, Julius Tomin held philosophy discussions with local residents in “home seminars”. A dissident in this country wrote about a grocer who holds a sign outside his window reading “Workers of the World, Unite!” in the essay “The Power of the Powerless.” Protesters jingled keys in this country to signify their support of the Civic Forum. Fictitious university student Martin (*) Smid went missing, inciting mass demonstrations in this country. Reformist manifestos in this country included the Two Thousand Words and Charter 77. The Soviet Union invaded this country in reaction to this country’s “socialism with a human face” initiative led by Alexander Dubcek. For 10 points, name this country, home to the 1968 Prague Spring.
tossups.answer: Czechoslovakia [or Czechoslovak Socialist Republic]

tossups.question: A series of lectures on this author were delivered by Józef Czapski in a Soviet prison camp. Terence Kilmartin revised an earlier translation of a book by this author, the first part of which was translated by Lydia Davis for Penguin Classics. This lover of the composer Reynaldo Hahn wrote about a homosexual encounter between a tailor and the (*) Baron de Charlus in the book Sodom and Gomorrah. C.K. Scott Moncrieff’s translation of this author’s most notable novel took its title from Shakespeare’s Sonnet 30. This creator of the Guermantes family wrote a passage in Swann’s Way where the narrator has an involuntary flashback after biting into a madeleine (“MAD-uh-len”). For 10 points, name this French author of the lengthy novel In Search of Lost Time.
tossups.answer: Marcel Proust

tossups.question: This product was responsible for the firing of US Marshal Wayne Ritchie, who held up a bar at gunpoint. George White set up a two-way mirror in a bedroom to entrap male prostitutes and give them this product in Operation Midnight Climax. Owsley Stanley’s Point Richmond home was a prominent source of this product. Ted Kaczynski (“kuh-CHIN-skee”) and Whitey (*) Bulger claimed to have been forcibly given this product. CIA director Richard Helms destroyed all files relating to Project MKULTRA, which involved the use of this product. Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters indulged in this product. This is the main product promoted with the phrase “turn on, tune in, drop out” by Timothy Leary. For 10 points, name this psychedelic drug.
tossups.answer: LSD [or lysergic acid diethylamide; or Delysid; prompt on acid]

tossups.question: One of these animals named Johannes accompanied Thor Heyerdahl aboard the raft Kon-Tiki. The long-tailed macaque, an invasive species native to Southeast Asia, is alternatively named for its habit of eating these animals. A Spanish idiom for daydreaming is “thinking about the immortality” of this animal, some of which are called Sally Lightfoots. A port city in Washington lends its name to this animal’s (*) Dungeness variety. The yellow crazy ant has killed millions of a red species of this animal that annually migrates across Christmas Island. The largest land-dwelling arthropods are a species of this animal that eats coconuts. One large claw is a hallmark of this animal’s fiddler type. For 10 points, name these crustaceans whose hermit type borrows shells.
tossups.answer: crabs [accept Dungeness crabs; or coconut crabs; or hermit crabs]

tossups.question: A composer from this country included the lyrics “Alleluia. May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest” in a song dedicated to the Greek actress Athene Heriades. Steven Isserlis commissioned a composer from this country to write the cantata The Protecting Veil. Although not the USSR, music from the canticle Abraham and Isaac and the the repeated use of a “C - F sharp” tritone feature prominently in the (*) Offertorium movement of a choral work from this country. One work from this country ends with a fugue that is introduced by the piccolo - the theme of that set of orchestral variations is based on the rondeau from incidental music to Abdelezar. For 10 points, name this home country of John Tavener and the composer of War Requiem and The Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra, Benjamin Britten.
tossups.answer: United Kingdom [or the U.K.; or Great Britain; or England; DO NOT accept or prompt on other constituents of the United Kingdom]

tossups.question: This quantity and the packing fraction are the two dimensionless coefficients needed for rheometric analysis of constant shear rate fluids. Two stress terms, the pore pressure, and this quantity appear in the equation for Coulomb stress transfer. This quantity is multiplied by rotation speed in the numerator of the Sommerfeld number, and the angle of repose is calculated as the (*) arctangent of one form of this quantity. This quantity appears on the y-axis of a Stribeck plot. Asperities are nano-scale imperfections that increase one form of this quantity. Applied force must exceed the product of normal force and this quantity to move a resting object on a flat surface. For 10 points, name this dimensionless quantity, symbolized mu, that has static and kinetic forms.
tossups.answer: coefficient of friction [or coefficient of static friction or coefficient of kinetic friction; accept mu-static or mu-kinetic; prompt on friction, static friction or COF or mu before mention]

tossups.question: These entities can be ascribed anthropomorphic properties due to their namesake "acts" according to a book by Guy Sircello that pairs these entities with "mind." The theory of make believe was applied to interactions with the representational variety of these entities by Kendall Walton. Drawing on the institutional theory of George Dickie, Arthur Danto argued that these entities are produced from cultural contexts and social institutions that make up these entities' namesake (*) world. These entities have experienced a decline of "aura" according to a Walter Benjamin essay about these entities in the "Age of Mechanical Reproduction." For 10 points, name these objects that are studied in aesthetics.
tossups.answer: artworks [or works of art; accept any reasonable answer that mentions art]

tossups.question: During this conflict, schoolteacher Diana Gould debated her country’s head of state on live TV. This conflict began when a group of scientists posing as scrap metal workers arrived at Leith Harbor and raised their country’s flag. Sandy Woodward ordered a controversial military action during this war while aboard the Conqueror. A soldier memorialized as “H. Jones” died at this conflict’s battle of (*) Goose Green. Leopoldo Galtieri’s “National Reorganization Process” government lost popularity after their defeat during this conflict. Troops invaded South Georgia Island during this conflict, which also saw the bombing of the General Belgrano. For 10 points, name this conflict, in which the UK and Argentina feuded over a small island country.
tossups.answer: Falklands War [or Falkland Islands War, or South Atlantic War, or Guerra de las Malvinas]

tossups.question: In one essay, Donald Posner discusses how recent trends in art history have opened discussion toward the “joyous sexuality of [this painting’s] imagery”. A 3D recreation of this painting incorporating ‘Dutch’ wax fabric and a lifesize headless mannequin was created by British-Nigerian artist Yinka Shonibare. An identically titled landscape by this painting’s artist is now housed in the National Gallery and was created to accompany his The (*) Blind Man’s Bluff. A man in green crouches in a bush below a statue of Cupid holding a finger to his lips in this painting’s lower-left corner to view the central scene, in which a woman in pink loses a shoe after being pushed on the title device. For 10 points, name this Rococo masterpiece by Jean-Honore Fragonard.
tossups.answer: (Happy Hazards of) The Swing (Shonibare’s piece is The Swing (After Fragonard))

tossups.question: Reacting bromobenzene with one of these compounds will produce biphenyl impurities. One of these compounds was reacted with a phenyl-aldehyde in the original derivation of Cram’s rule of asymmetric induction. A palladium catalyst undergoes transmetalation with one of these compounds prior to the elimination step in the Kumada coupling. A guard tube containing calcium chloride is commonly employed to maintain (*) air free conditions when preparing these compounds. While dissolved in solvents like THF, these compounds redistribute according to Schlenk equilibrium. Two equivalents of these compounds reduce an ester to a tertiary alcohol, and they are used to form new C-C bonds with carbonyls. For 10 points, name these organomagnesium reagents named for a French chemist.
tossups.answer: Grignard reagent [prompt on organomagnesium reagents before mentioned]

tossups.question: After a servant in this play asks “Why are you thus out of measure / Sad?”, his master responds “I cannot hide what I am.” Another character in this play says if she were a man, she would “eat his heart in the marketplace.” A woman in this play is “done to death by slanderous tongues,” according to an epitaph read at the tomb of a character falsely believed to be dead from shock. (*) Balthasar sings about “Converting all your sounds of woe / Into hey, nonny nonny” in a song from this play beginning “Sigh no more, ladies.” The line “Forget not that I am an ass” is delivered by the incompetent police constable Dogberry in this play. In a subplot of this play, Claudio tests the fidelity of his fiancée Hero. For 10 points, name this Shakespearean comedy about the bickering couple Beatrice and Benedick.
tossups.answer: Much Ado About Nothing

tossups.question: . In the Philippines, this holiday can be celebrated with a Kalag-Kalag feast and coconut wine and this holiday is sometimes known as Undas. Celebrants of this holiday may decorate with fake marigold flowers or use their petals to create paths leading to their front doors. A cartoon of a woman wearing an oversized hat with two feathers inspired this holiday's practice of reading humorous epitaphs. Elaborately cut (*) tissue paper known as papel picado is used to decorate tombstones during this holiday, whose main celebration centers on the family ofrenda, or altar. Often associated with All Souls Day and incorrectly conflated with Halloween is, for 10 points, what Mexican holiday celebrated in honor of deceased relatives?
tossups.answer: Dia de los Muertos [or Dia de Muertos; or Day of the Dead; accept All Saints Day; accept All Souls Day before mentioned; accept Undas before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "Halloween" or "All Hallow's Eve"]

tossups.question: In probability theory, this letter names a discrete distribution whose pdf equals “1 over x to the shape parameter” times the sum from “i equals 1 to n” of “1 over i to the shape parameter”. Observations of Shafranov kink instabilities led Lyman Spitzer to target a fusion reactor known by this Greek letter to retract data in the 1960s. A quantity named for this letter is measured at the slipping plane of an interfacial (*) double layer, and represents the potential difference between a dispersion medium and a fluid’s stationary layer. In classical mechanics, this letter is used to represent an oscillator’s damping ratio, as well as the potential describing colloid electrostatics. For 10 points, identify this Greek letter that names the function subject to the Riemann hypothesis.
tossups.answer: zeta [accept zeta distribution, ZETA reactor or Zero Energy Thermonuclear Assembly Reactor, zeta potential or Riemann Zeta function; do not accept or prompt on ‘Z’]

tossups.question: Groups of peasants during this dynasty were conscripted into local militias that would mobilize during emergencies in the fubing system. The first Christian missionary to reach China, Alopen, arrived during this dynasty. An emperor of this dynasty took the title Tian Kehan after defeating Turkish nomads. That emperor took power by killing his brothers at the Xuanwu Gate. A traveller from this dynasty spent time in the (*) Nalanda monastery and gained the favor of King Harsha. A half-Sogdian general’s rebellion marked the decline of this dynasty, which some blamed on the legendary concubine Yang Guifei. Xuanzang started his 16-year journey from this dynasty’s capital, Chang’an. For 10 points, name this dynasty which followed the Sui Dynasty.
tossups.answer: Tang Dynasty

tossups.question: A photographer for this magazine spent 6 years traveling to remote locations like the Republic of Dahomey to create a series of ethnographic holiday photos like “Christmas at Cuzco.” While employed by this magazine, that photographer of “Still Life with Ace of Hearts” created a black and white portrait of Igor Stravinsky dramatically wedged into a corner. Irving Penn was a longtime photographer for this magazine, which in the 1940’s commissioned Lee Miller’s iconic photograph in Hitler’s (*) bathtub. More recently, this magazine provoked controversy for a cover where Lebron James and Gisele Bundchen stand in a pose reminiscent of King Kong. For 10 points, name this fashion magazine edited since 1988 by Anna Wintour.
tossups.answer: Vogue

tossups.question: According to the "New Interpretation" of this thinker put forward by Roy J. Ruffin, this man's "four magic numbers" do not represent the ratios of labor input coefficients. Joan Robinson argued that this thinker's most famous idea would only be valid in cases of static equilibrium. In The Production of Commodities by Means of Commodities Piero Sraffa championed this non-Keynes thinker's (*) "neo" form of economics. According to one principle formulated by this thinker, real wages tend towards the minimum level necessary to support the survival of workers. This formulator of the "Iron Law of Wages" illustrated another concept using English cloth and Portuguese wine. For 10 points, name this author of Principles of Political Economy and Taxation, who formulated the concept of comparative advantage.
tossups.answer: David Ricardo

tossups.question: Ian Sansom wrote a 2019 “biography” of this poem, which its author claimed “was infected with an incurable dishonesty - and must be scrapped.” After 9/11, this poem regained popularity due to passages like one about “blind skyscrapers” that “use / Their full height to proclaim / The strength of Collective Man.” This poem notes “each woman and each man / Craves” “not universal love, but to be (*) loved alone.” It asks “What huge imago made / A psychopathic god” before saying “all schoolchildren learn, / Those to whom evil is done / Do evil in return.” This poem’s narrator sits in “one of the dives / On Fifty-second Street” and proclaims “We must love one another or die.” For 10 points, name this W.H. Auden poem named for the date Germany invaded Poland.
tossups.answer: “September 1, 1939”

bonuses.leadin: Howard Dean found out his brother was killed by this group before taking an organic chemistry exam, which he promptly failed. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this guerrilla group that nominally served under King Souvanna Phouma and was controlled by the “Red Prince”, Souvanna’s half-brother.
The Pathet Lao threatened to exterminate this ethnic group to “to the last root”. A 1997 book by Anne Fadiman centers on a family of this ethnicity at Merced Hospital.
Hmong settlers moved into this nearby country after the Vietnam War. Pol Pot exterminated 25% of this country’s population while heading the Khmer Rouge.

bonuses.leadin: In The Meaning of this school of thought, one philosopher argued that this school of thought was only tenuously connected with the free market economy. For 10 points each:
answer: The Second Sex [or Le deuxième sexe]
parts: Name this school of thought, whose modern form was founded by Edmund Burke in Reflections on the Revolution in France.

This recently deceased conservative philosopher wrote The Meaning of Conservatism. In How to Be a Conservative, this philosopher outlined ways that conservative ideas can be applied to modern problems or debates, while in Sexual Desire this philsopher argued that homosexuality was a perverted form of masturbation.

In Sexual Desire, Scruton dismisses this book as "Kantian feminism." This key feminist text was published in the volumes "Facts and Myths" and "Lived Experience" and includes the argument that "marriage always destroys" its title people.

bonuses.leadin: The law of this kind of city was proposed by Mark Jefferson, who argued that they must be twice as large and twice as important as the next largest city in their country. For 10 points each:
answer: London and New York City [accept NYC for New York City]
parts: Give this term for a city that is vastly more important than any other urban area in its region or country.

This city is often held to be the most primate of all primate cities, as it is over 30 times larger than its country's next largest city, Korat. This city was founded by King Rama I, who also founded the Chakri Dynasty, which still rules from this capital of Thailand.

In the GaWC world city rankings, these are the only two cities to receive the rank of Alpha ++. In the book The Global City, Saskia Sassen listed these two cities along with Tokyo as being the "command centers" for Global Commerce.

bonuses.leadin: Minor characters in this novel such as Pan Jinlian are given the starring role in the sexually explicit novel The Plum in the Golden Vase. For 10 points each:
answer: Water Margin [or Shuihu Zhuan; or Outlaws of the Marsh; or Tale of the Marshes, or All Men Are Brothers, or Men of the Marshes; or The Marshes of Mount Liang]
Stars of Destiny [or Stars of Heavenly Earth; or Stars of Heaven and Earth]
parts: Name this one of the "Four Great Classical Novels" written by Shi Nai'an, which follows the lives of a group of bandits led by Song Jiang.

Song Jiang is the leader of this group of outlaws, who were a group of banished spirits accidentally reborn on earth as 108 men. This group of outlaws is broken into the 36 Heavenly Spirits and the 72 Earthly Fiends.

This American author wrote a controversial translation of Water Margin titled All Men Are Brothers. This author also wrote a trilogy of novels about Chinese peasant life in novels such as Sons and A House Divided.

bonuses.leadin: The discovery that one organism in this genus would ovulate in response to injections of human urine containing hCG led to their use in one of the earliest successful pregnancy tests. For 10 points each:
answer: Xenopus [accept Xenopus laevis or Xenopus tropicalis; accept African clawed frog]
fertilization of the egg [accept dpf or hpf or days post fertilization or hours post fertilization]
parts: Name this genus of frog commonly employed in developmental biology research for their large, clear oocytes. Spemann and Mangold discovered the “organizer” region in this genus’ laevis species.

Another pioneering experiment making use of Xenopus demonstrated that “cap” cells from the embryonic hemisphere described by this adjective retained competence when grafted onto the corresponding vegetal pole cells.

Xenopus embryos are also useful for their clearly defined developmental stages. For example, Xenopus embryos are known to begin blastulation roughly 3 hours post-[this event] and to begin gastrulation roughly 7 hours post-[this event]. In this event, two gametes fuse to form the embryo.

bonuses.leadin: In The Tale of Chunhyang, a buk one of these instruments played by a gosu accompanies the singer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these instruments, the taiko version of which is featured prominently in traditional Japanese music.

The Tale of Chunhyang is one of the traditional musical works from this country. Like many pieces of traditional music from this country, The Tale of Chunhyang takes place during this country's Joseon Dynasty.

The Tale of Chunhyang is a famous example of this genre of traditional Korean performance. The performance of this genre includes the elements of jo, jangdan, buchimsae, and je. Of the traditional 12 song cycles of this genre, only 5 are performed today.

bonuses.leadin: The first book of this composition opens with an Evocation that switches between A-flat minor and A-flat major, and its third movement depicts a Corpus Christi Day celebration. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this composition for solo piano. The first full length recording of this Spanish work was given by Alicia de Larrocha, and Ida Rubinstein commissioned Maurice Ravel to orchestrate 6 movements from this work.

The composer of Iberia, Isaac Albeniz, is from this region of north-eastern Spain. Miguel Llobet, who transcribed the popular folk song “El Testament d’Amèlia”, was born in this region’s capital of Barcelona.
This Barcelona-born tenor recorded many folk songs for the album [this man] Sings Catalan Songs. He is the only member of the Three Tenors that is from Catalonia.

bonuses.leadin: This man murdered nobleman Carlos de la Cerda in an inn after having a public argument with him in Paris. For 10 points:
answer: Charles the Bad of Navarre [or Charles II, King of Navarre; prompt on Charles]
parts: Name this notorious ruler who was accidentally burnt alive by his nurse while wrapped in a linen sack soaked in brandy.

Charles the Bad put down this rebellion and tortured its leader at the Battle of Mello. This French peasant rebellion was led by a man colloquially called “Jack Goodfellow”, though his real name was Guillaume Cale.

Charles the Bad’s ruthlessness was described in the Chronicles by Jean Froissart, which documented this war’s progress. The Jacquerie broke out after the capture of John II of France at the Battle of Poitiers in this war.

bonuses.leadin: The American version of the video game Castlevania: Symphony of the Night stole the quote “What is a man? A miserable little pile of secrets” from this author. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of a 1968 collection of “anti-memoirs.” Ch’en Ta Erh dies in an unsuccessful suicide bombing meant to kill Chiang Kai-Shek in his novel Man’s Fate.
This author coined the term “anti-novel” in his preface to Nathalie Sarraute's book Portrait of a Man Unknown. This existentialist wrote the play No Exit.
Many anti-tales, or fairy tales which have tragic endings, were adapted from stories compiled by this 17th-century Frenchman who wrote Tales of Mother Goose and the original “Cinderella.”

bonuses.leadin: In the latest game created by this studio, the user controls an unnamed boy and the chimeric like creature Trico. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this studio, which started work on The Last Guardian before SIE took over. In this studio's namesake first game, the player controls a horned boy who escorts the cursed girl Yorda.
Team Ico also created this game, where Wander and his faithful horse Agro slays the 16 title creatures in an unwitting quest to release the evil spirits called Dormin.
All three of Team Ico's games were released on the Playstation 2 and Playstation 3, which were created by this Japanese electronics and entertainment conglomerate.

bonuses.leadin: Thomas Kelly introduced skepticism about the occurrence of a battle this city won because Pausanias is the lone ancient source for it. For 10 points each:
answer: Alexander the Great [accept Alexander III of Macedon; prompt on Alexander]
parts: Name this city that defeated Sparta at the 669 BCE Battle of Hysiae under the leadership of the tyrant Pheidon.
This king was killed during an invasion of Argos after an old woman threw a tile on his head. The Romans called this ruler’s war elephants “Lucanian oxen.”
This ruler is traditionally thought to have his dynastic roots in Argos. This ruler’s own military victories include Gaugamela and Issus.

bonuses.leadin: During the havdalah ceremony, a braided example of these objects is blessed alongside a bowl of wine. For 10 points each:
answer: Tabernacle [or Tent of Congregation; or Tent of Meeting]
parts: Name these objects, 9 of which are lit during Hanukkah.

This is the term for the "helper" candle used during Hanukkah celebration. This candle must be placed in the center holder of the Menorah and raised above the other candles in order to satisfy Jewish law.
According to the Torah, this structure housed a 6 branched Menorah, which was lit daily with pure olive oil. This structure was the original holding place of the Ark of the Covenant.

bonuses.leadin: The 2019 Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics went to the team of Ferrara, Freedman, and van Nieuwenhuizen for their work developing this field in the 1970’s. For 10 points each:
answer: supergravity theory [accept SUGRA or SUEGRA; prompt on gravity]
parts: Name this modern field theory that combines supersymmetry with general relativity and the Standard Model. Theories within this field of physics are referred to as “extended” when they apply to more than 1 super-symmetry.

The initial formulation of supergravity was put forth with a value of 4 for this quantity; however, later theories with values of 11 for this quantity drew great interest as a potential “theory of everything” candidate. Minkowski space has a value of 4 for this quantity, since it treats space and time as a continuum.

Edward Witten put forth this unification of all superstring theories in large part due to the failures of 11-dimensional supergravity as a theory of everything. Loop quantum gravity is the primary rival to this theory.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Gowan overhears his wife discuss why she believes the life of Nancy should be spared after Nancy murdered their child. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sequel that takes place eight years after a novel in which the Ole Miss student Temple Drake is raped by Popeye and is given a job at a brothel.
This Mississippian author of Requiem for a Nun also wrote As I Lay Dying and The Sound and the Fury.

Requiem for a Nun is the source of the quote “[this thing] is never dead. It’s not even [this thing].” The last line of The Great Gatsby reads “So we beat on, boats against the current, borne ceaselessly against [this thing].”

bonuses.leadin: By definition, these substances possess compressibility factors that do not equal one. For 10 points each:
answer: real gas(es) [accept non-ideal gasses; prompt on gas]
Poynting factor [or Poynting correction factor or Poynting effect]
parts: Name these substances whose behaviors are affected by their molar volume, molecular weight, and other factors that prevent them from accurately being described by the equation PV=nRT.

This quantity is equal to the pressure required for a real gas to have the same chemical potential as an ideal gas. In general, this quantity measures the tendency of a molecule to escape its current phase.
When calculating the fugacity of a substance in vapor-liquid equilibrium at high pressures, this correction factor must be added to account for the change in pressure from the saturated phase.

bonuses.leadin: Judge Charles Kaufman only gave Ronald Ebens and Michael Nitz a $3,000 fine and three years of jail time for killing this man after mistaking him for Japanese. For 10 points each:
answer: George Romney [or George Wilcken Romney; prompt on Romney]
parts: Name this Chinese man who was killed outside of a McDonald’s in 1982 after an encounter at the Fancy Pants strip club.

Chin was murdered in this major U.S. city. This major city was home to an anti-Semitic businessman who once remarked “any customer can have a car painted any color that he wants, so long as it is black.”
Earlier racial violence was sparked in Detroit during the governorship of this politician in 1967. This man’s 1968 presidential campaign torpedoed after he said he was “brainwashed” in Vietnam.

bonuses.leadin: This poem references a book by Germaine de Staël in a scene where its protagonist crowns herself with a wreath made of ivy. For 10 points each:
answer: Lord Byron [or George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron]
parts: Name this epic poem. Lady Waldemar interferes in the planned marriage between Romney and Marian Erle in this poem.
Aurora Leigh was written by this fan of Germaine de Staël’s novel Corinne, whose Sonnets from the Portuguese contains the line “How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.”

Germaine de Staël befriended this author, who called her “the most eminent author of this, or perhaps of any, century.” This man’s lover Caroline Lamb described him as “mad, bad, and dangerous to know.”

bonuses.leadin: The Hornbach sacramentary is a work from this artistic period that exemplifies the popular trend of “presentation miniatures” depicting interactions between secular and clerical nobility. For 10 points each:
answer: Ottonian Renaissance [accept just Otto; prompt on pre-Romanesque period]
parts: Name this 10th century artistic “Renaissance” named for a sequence of three Holy Roman Emperors. Gregory Master is one of the foremost artists of this period, which was shorter than the Carolingian Renaissance before it.

One of the most notable artworks from the Ottonian Renaissance is a set of these objects produced in bronze for Hildesheim Cathedral that depict scenes from the Book of Genesis and are named for their patron, Bishop Bernward.

Both the Hornbach sacramentary and Gregory Master’s Codex Egberti are examples of this general type of artwork produced during the Ottonian era. Psalters are another example of the “illuminated” type of these artworks.

bonuses.leadin: According to the activist group Critical Resistance, the rise of these institution's industrial-complex is a response to societal issues such as homelessness and gender nonconformity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these institutions, whose mass use was linked to slavery and segregation by Michelle Alexander in her book, The New Jim Crow.

This activist and author co-founded Critical Resistance with Ruth Wilson Gilmore. This activist detailed the history of the women's liberation movement in the United States and highlighted the exclusion of Black women from feminist discourse in her book Women, Race, and Class.

Angela Davis studied at a university in this European city under the philosopher Herbert Marcuse. That university in this city is also associated with the Max Horkeimer led Institute for Social Research and a namesake school of Western Marxism.

bonuses.leadin: This substance typically forms when pahoehoe lava falls into the sea, but rarely forms when aa lava makes contact with water. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this primarily basaltic substance that forms during the eruption of underwater volcanoes. The namesake structures in this substance tend to be larger for increasingly felsic lavas.

Pillow lava typically forms the uppermost level in Layer 2 of oceanic crust, which is itself the top layer in these pieces of the earth’s crust whose movement atop the mantle is the basis of a theory expanding upon continental drift.

The presence of pillow lava has been useful for dating greenstone belts, which are regions separating gneiss and granite within these oldest and strongest sections of the Earth’s crust. Continental shields are exposed regions of these structures.
